Award.AwardTitle: High Speed Friction Stir Spot Welding: A New Approach to Spot Joining of Ultra High Strength Steel

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to test the hypothesis that joint bond area in friction stir spot welding of ultra-high strength steel is determined largely by interface pressure, interface temperature, and weld time. Welding speeds in the range of 5,000 to 10,000 revolutions per minute will be considered, and the welding process will be constrained to a maximum vertical welding load of eight kilonewtons, with a goal of achieving a desired level of joint strength. A novel approach to modeling friction stir spot welding will be used within a Lagrangian finite element framework, where the joint interface will be represented virtually and where a proposed relationship between joint contact pressures, temperatures, and weld time will be used to estimate bond area. Archard's law will be used within the model to estimate tool wear. An experimental program will measure joint strength and tool wear over time, while microstructural evaluation of the joints will provide insight into the effect of tool wear on bonding mechanisms.

If successful, this project will enable the use of friction stir spot welding for joining ultra-high strength steel sheet in many industrial settings. The modeling approach will provide increased understanding of the role of tool design and process conditions on joint strength and tool life. Finding a solution to spot joining of ultra-high strength steels is important because these alloys have the potential to make car frames lighter and stiffer, improving vehicle fuel economy and reducing carbon emissions. The widespread use of ultra-high strength steel is currently limited by brittle weld microstructures produced by traditional resistance spot welding.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lightweighting of vehicle structures is an important effort being addressed by automakers, national labs, and by university researchers. Aggressive government targets for improvement of fuel efficiency and a corresponding decrease in emission of greenhouse gases is driving these efforts. The corporate average fuel economy (CAFE) standard for passeger cars was 27.5 miles per gallon (mpg) from 1990 through 2010. In 2011 the standard rose to 30.2 mpg, and in 2020 it will reach 49 mpg, for smaller passenger cars.

The use of advanced high strength steel (AHSS) alloys is an important part of the lightweighting process. Thinner gauges of sheet can be used, while maintaining or enhancing crash resistance. However, the spot welding of AHSS is problematic. These steels shave higher alloy content and are therefore more hardenable that mild steel. Brittle microstructures and small cracks can develop when these alloys are spot welded, which limits durability.

This project focused on the friction stir spot welding (FSSW) of AHSS, as an alternative to resistance spot welding. A large number of experiments were performed in order to characterize the strength of joints bonded by FSSW in dual phase (DP) 980 steel, using a polycrystalline cubic boron nitride (PCBN) tool. PCBN was used as a tool material, because it has high enough hardness to resist wear that is caused by friction and high temperatures. It was found that sufficent joint strength could be obtained, as evaluated by lap shear and cross tension testing.  However, the life of a tool used to perform the welding was limited to about 1000 welds in the best case.  In addition, the wear mechanism of the tool was postulated to be grain pullout, based on the experimental evidence. This conclusion was reached after performing thousands of welding experiments using three different grades of PCBN tools on DP 980 steel.  In addition to providing a better understanding of the wear mechanism, it was found that smaller CBN grain size correlated to greater tool life.

Modeling of the FSSW process was performed using a finite element approach. A novel two dimenensional approximation was employed in order to limit the amount of time needed to carry out the simulation. Thermocouple measurements were done during spot welding experiments in order to validate the temperature predictions of the model.  It was found that the model predicted welding temperatures in three different locations near the stir zone to within 4% or better. The model also predicted bond area, which is related to joint strength, to within 10% of the experiments. 

In parallel with the technical work, an outreach effort was sustained over the course of the project with a high school teacher who developed a new class called "materials and processes".  The purpose of the course was to combine principles of engineering design with manufacturing processes, in order to help students understand the links between them.  We hosted students from the class for lab exercises at BYU over several years, and helped the teacher purchase equipment to enhance student learning in her local laboratory.

In summary, the results of the project have quantified joint strength and tool life for FSSW of DP 980 steel using a PCBN tool. The wear mechanism for PCBN tools applied to FSSW of high strength steel was determined from a large body of experimental evidence. And a novel approach to the modeling of FSSW was developed and validated. This work has laid a foundation for continued development of FSSW as an enabling technology for the lightweighting of automotive and other structures.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2015
Modified by: Michael P Miles
